results.abstract: Actor Harrison Ford's reputation as practical joker on set of his new movie K-19: The Widowmaker discussed; former New York City Parks Commissioner Henry J Stern breaks several bones in fall; actor Peter Boyle of television's Everybody Loves Raymond has gallbladder removed; stars gather for summer barbeque in Central Park for Joseph Papp Public Theater/New York Shakespeare Festival before performance of Twelfth Night; Russia accepts 'N Sync singer Lance Bass to be third tourist in space; Marlo Thomas takes over role in play The Guys about Sept 11 terrorist attacks; environmental group Standing for Truth About Radiation prepares to honor environmental heroes, including Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton; photos (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PAPP, JOSEPH, PUBLIC THEATER/NEW YORK SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL

results.snippet: An Actor's Sort of Joke      There are those -- the reporters who covered the New York premiere of the cold war thriller ''K-19: The Widowmaker'' on Thursday, for example -- who would say that HARRISON FORD, left, is kind of like Mount Rushmore:...
results.section_name: Movies; Theater; New York and Region

byline.original: By James Barron, With Linda Lee

results.lead_paragraph: An Actor's Sort of Joke There are those -- the reporters who covered the New York premiere of the cold war thriller ''K-19: The Widowmaker'' on Thursday, for example -- who would say that HARRISON FORD, left, is kind of like Mount Rushmore: familiar, craggy and not terribly talkative. But along comes the actor CHRISTIAN CAMARGO, countering that Mr. Ford is not without humor. Do tell. Mr. Camargo, who plays a young officer in Mr. Ford's thriller ''K-19: The Widowmaker,'' said the crew played practical jokes. On the set was a scene-disrupting noisemaker. Looking angry, Mr. Ford grabbed the noisemaker and announced that it was time to do the scene the cast had been rehearsing, Mr. Camargo said. ''Everytime he spoke it was brilliant, you know, brilliant, and then it would be somebody else's line, and you'd hear the noise,'' Mr. Camargo continued. ''He had that gizmo in his hand. It probably cost the producers half a day of money down the drain, but we were on the floor laughing.''
